newsitem.title: INDONESIA: INTERVIEW-Fidelity sees value in Indonesia stocks.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Fidelity sees value in Indonesia stocks.

text.p: The world's leading mutual funds company, Fidelity Investments, has said Indonesian stocks have good but not exceptional value and looked attractive in the longer-term.

"We think Indonesia is good value. But we don't think it has exceptional value," Stuart Leckie, chairman of Fidelity Investments, told Reuters in an interview on Sunday. "In the long-term, it is attractive."
"We don't think it's overvalued. Our weighting is just about in line with the emerging market index," Leckie said.
Leckie said he had been very pleased with developments in Indonesia since the stock market was liberalised and deregulated in 1988.
"I think since then the market has developed very well indeed," he said during a conference on the island of Bali on capital flows to the region.
"One of the things which need to be clarified in due course is the succesion plan," Leckie said, referring to the question over who would succeed long-ruling President Suharto.
Suharto, 75, has been in power since the mid-1960s and he has no obvious successors.
Leckie said he would also like to see more deregulation in pension fund laws.
"Indonesia wants to attract foreign pension funds, why not allow local pension funds to invest abroad," Leckie said.
Leckie said Fidelity had no plan to open an office in Indonesia in the short-term.
"We are very interested in Indonesia. In the medium-term we might have a presence here," he said.
